Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.p: THE ROVND-HEADS REMEMBRANCER: OR, A true and particular Relation of the great defeat given to the Rebels by His Majesties good Subjects of the County of Cornwall, under the Command of Sr RALPH HOPTON, on Tuesday May 16. 1643.

div.head: A true Relation of the great Defeat given to the Rebels by His Majesties good Subjects of the County of Cornwall, under the Command of Sr RALPH HOPTON. May 16. 1643.
div.p:
NOthing is more frequent with the Agents in this Rebellion, then to fasten their Treasons on God and Religion. If they plunder and rob a mans house, those stoln goods are presently the gifts of God. If they fight and are beaten, then either they deny it, and give thanks for a victory; or else confesse some small losse, which God sent to them by his speciall Providence to draw the Cavaleirs into further destruction. And if at any time they prosper and prevaile over the Kings forces by stealing on them in their beds, by a perfidious Treaty, or some other worse meanes, then each thread and particle of their successe is the Wonderfull worke of God. Thus Wallers entring Hereford is
Burrough •
in a Sermon at London stil'd as great a Deliverance as the Israëlites passage through the Red sea; and his Excellencies gaining Reading they
Sedgwick at Reading May. 21. call no lesse a miracle then the razing downe the walls of Jericho with pitchers and Rams horns. Nor is this strange, for they who are come up to that desperate impudence to shoot at the King, and say it is to save his life, will likewise blaspheme God to his honour and glory. And though they know, that we know they are guilty of such villanies as the Devill can scarce exceed, yet God must be the Father of whatsoever they bring forth, and sometimes too before the birth: For on Tuesday the 16th of this moneth,
when the Westerne Rebells received this defeat, on that very day the holy garrison in Warwicke had a solemne Thanksgiving for a new great victory over Sir Ralph Hopton; but whether God hath suffered himselfe to be mocked, let posterity judge.

It is true the Earle of Stamford marched out of Exeter with almost as much pomp and vainglory as his Excellencie, himselfe when he first advanced through London streetes, promising all their party to conquer Cornwall at this one blow. And to this purpose he had summoned in all the strength he could possibly make, and by perswasions and threats got together betwixt five and 6000 foot. The Country people remembred what faire Articles Sir Ralph Hopton and the Cornish Gentry had made for Peace, how often the Committee for the two Houses had refused Peace, though themselves had sworn to it, and sealed it with the Sacrament (which perjury God will one day punish either here or hereafter, if he have not begun it already) and that nothing but bloud would appease the Rebells ambition. These and the like thoughts retarded the people from being forward to this Battaile. Yet the Earle of Stamford is so noble a Lord, that if it ly in his power, no man shall keepe his Allegiance, nor any woman her chastity. Finding therefore the Country unwilling to come in to him, he rages horribly on divers who refused, plundering them so bare, that Master Martin (the Plundermaster Generall) himselfe could have gone no higher. Others he smooths and strokes with fine promises, that they should not need to strike a blow, onely appeare and shew their faces, and they should see him bring the Rebell Hopton into Exeter dead or alive. Which was bravely said (you'l think) and had more truth in it, then his Lordship imagined, having already brought Sir Ralph very neare the very walls of Exeter. In the meane time you see the world is come to a fine passe, when the most groundlesse Rebellion that ever was heard or read of, must be Gods owne cause; and those loyall Gentlemen (who love their conscience better then their bloud) must be voted for Rebells. Which certainly would be the very top of all their villanies, if these
Rebells had not now outdone themselves, and (which all good men tremble to think of) accused and voted the QUEENS MAJESTY guilty of High Treason, for helping the King (her owne Lord and Husband) against the worst of Rebells in his owne Kingdome.

The Rebells having thus gotten their forces together, away they advance to Stratton in Cornwall, a Towne close upon the borders of Devonshire; and neare this towne they intrenched in as strong a Camp, as (themselves confesse) they ever yet beheld. Two dayes before the blow was struck they ordained a solemne Fast (which was held at Exeter) for the good successe of this great action; one of the Preachers (as some that heard him have certified) confidently declared, that God would manifest the justice of the cause by the successe of that dayes worke when ever the two Armies came to joyne. And now were these Westerne Rebells exactly at the highest (for when Rebels fast they are commonly most confident) for men, Ordnance, Ammunition, place, Armes, and all other Accommodation never so strong before, but strongest of all in the weaknesse of their enemy. For indeed Sir Ralph Hopton was never so low as now, his whole body of foot being not full 3000, and his Ammunition not sufficient for those men hee had, as appeared in the event. Yet Sir Ralph and those other noble Gentlemen, did not only prepare to meet the Rebells in the field, but (to the perpetuall honour of the County of Cornwall) assaulted this great Rebellious body in their strong workes and trenches, fighting bravely with them for full 10 houres, and when these loyall gentlemen had spent their Ammunition, and had not powder left for one houre longer, they then (with unexpressible valour) fell upon the Rebels with their swords and pikes, and fought it out so manfully, that at last they wholly routed the Rebels Army, killed many hundreds of them dead in the place, wounded many more; tooke 1700 prisoners, whereof above 30 Commanders, as Chudleigh Sergeant Major Generall of their Army, Sr Robert Wingfield, with divers other Sergeant Majors and Captaines; and of Common Souldiers more then they know what to doe with.
Among those that were slaine, one was Colmaddy Lieutenant Colonell to the Generall, with many others of best quality amongst them. They tooke likewise all the Rebels Canon, being 11 peeces of brasse Ordinance, and 1 brasse Mortar for Granadoes, besides 4 iron peeces and 1 Iron Mortar. In Ammunition they tooke 57 barrels of powder, with a like proportionable quantity of bullet, shot, match, and betwixt 2 and 3000 armes, besides 3000l in ready money. There were killed and hurt of the Kings Forces 46 Common souldiers, but not any one Commander, or Gentleman of quality.

And now let the Reader judge, if ever the Rebels had a more shamefull defeate; and whether the Gentry and Commons of the County of Cornwall deserve not to be recorded to all posterity for most loyall and valiant for their King and Country. What a horrour this hath strucke in the remnant of those Rebels who are now at Exeter, you may better discerne from their owne hands, more particularly by this intercepted Letter, which was going to London from a Cheife Member of their faction.

body.p:
Since your departure, I received only two Letters, the one the 19, the other the 20 of this moneth. Sir Ralph Hopton is at Okington, and its doubted will very speedily distresse Exeter; those horse of ours which escaped are now here, but much wearied out; they came hither from Bodmin yesterday morning. These inclosed Letters, were taken from Doctor Coxe, who came with a trumpeter
with Letters to the Commanders here, offering quarter if we would submit; both are yet imprisoned, and Doctor Coxe who came with a Trumpeter when the Lord Generall said he should be searched for Letters did swallow a paper, and the Trumpeter shewed another in small peeces: they came in last even. The Trained Bands refuse to appeare to assist us, so that wee can hardly hearten on our souldiers; but in Exeter there is a considerable number of Citizens, and wee have summoned in all the Armes of the East, lest Sir Ralph Hopton take them too with the Posse. Wee hope to have speedy assistance, before which time wee cannot raise any Force. For now the hearts of Parliaments friends are down, and many daily drop off from us. VVe can do little for want of Armes, which if not speedily sent will do us little good, therefore we beseech you speed them to us. Major Chudleigh is turned against us. The newes you wrote to Master Crossing doth somewhat revive us. The Volunteers will not do the worke I feare; if any experienced religious souldiers be to be gotten from London I wish we had them speedily sent us. Our men went on resolutely at this last fight at Stratton, being assured that our Horse would countenance them in the Reare; but when they were charged with the Horse
of the enemy, and ours did not what we expected, we were discouraged, and so the enemy by the help of their Horse broke in upon our Foot and routed us, taking all our Cannon, and most of our Ammunition. VVe hoped this day would have ended the work, and so the Posse would have vanished of it's owne accord But God hath otherwise determined yet further to humble us. Our confidence on the arme of flesh (which was our strong Army) was too great &c.

div.p: There's none that considers the whole progresse of the Westerne Affaires from the businesse of Sherborne Castle to this very day, but may clearely see the reward of Loyalty and scourge of Rebellion. And how this one single County having (through its distance from Court) received no supply of Forces from His Majestie, nor any assistance by influence of the Kings Counsell for better direction in their daily occasions, hath yet (by the extraordinary mercy and blessing of God) maintained an Army for their King and Country, fighting many Battailes, and obtaining many Victories, to the shame and amazement of their numerous Enemies, and the everlasting honour of the County of CORNWALL.
